newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Two S.Korean soldiers, two agents dead in shootout.
newsitem.headline: Two S.Korean soldiers, two agents dead in shootout.

text.p: One South Korean soldier and two North Korean infiltrators were killed on Sunday during a fierce shootout in rugged east coast mountains, a defence ministry spokesman said.
A second Southern soldier later died of his injuries after the clash at dawn.

The latest casualties bring to nine the number of North Koreans killed by Southern forces in a hunt for an estimated 26 communist agents who landed by submarine on Wednesday on a beach near the east coast city of Kangnung.
Eleven other agents were found shot dead, possibly killed by their colleagues, and one was captured alive.
A total of three Southern troops have now been reported killed in a deadly game of cat-and-mouse over mountain trails covered with thick vegetation.

A Southern paratrooper was killed on Saturday. According to some reports he was hit while dangling on a winch line from a helicopter that was lowering him to the ground. Another paratrooper was injured.

An army officer in Kangnung said one of the North Koreans killed on Sunday was wearing a Southern army uniform while the other was in civilian clothes. He said a rifle and a grenade were found at the scene.
Thousands of troops backed by helicopters have been engaged in a massive manhunt to end one of the deadlist operations from the enemy North since the early Cold War.
South and North Korea have been technically at war since their 1950-53 conflict ended only with an armistice agreement.

Details of the Northern infiltration remain confused, although the defence ministry believes that among the agents were three elite saboteurs, and they may have been responsible for the execution-style killings of the 11 on Wednesday in a ruthless bid to improve their own survival chances.

Authorities trying to unravel the mystery of the mission -- which ran into serious trouble when the submarine grounded on a reef -- are relying on statements from the captured North Korean agent, who has changed his story several times.
The Hankook Ilbo daily on Sunday quoted agent Lee Kwang-soo as telling interrogators the team carried high explosives.
It said this suggested the mission could be have been intended to carry out a terrorist-style attack or to destroy important facilities.
Lee was quoted as saying the explosives may have been thrown into the sea or hidden on land.
Other newspapers focussed on what appeared to be sloppy methods adopted by North Koreans, whose past missions have often been meticulous, and clinically violent.
After abandoning their stricken submarine, they initially left a trail of personal belongings, including keys and clothes, and a life jacket that betrayed their movements.

Two of them barged into a villager's home and stole cigarettes and food at gunpoint, and then left leaving the owner shaken but unharmed. Hardened commandos might have silently killed civilians to cover their tracks.

The three infiltrators shot on Thursday had no survival equipment, wore jeans and sneakers, and had only one pistol between them. Media reports said a taxi driver found them sitting on a rock smoking cigarettes.
One explanation is that some of the agents were members of the submarine crew who never intended to come ashore.

Yonhap news agency quoted investigators as saying they had recovered two artillery pieces with a range of 8 km (5 miles), an anti-tank recoilless gun and a Czech-made machinegun after a thorough search of the submarine.
Divers had successfully removed a timebomb attached to the bottom of the vessel.
